entry.title: Day 22
entry.content:
Today’s Progress

I continued on with my MongoDB course, and set up some GET requests, and test cases on the todo API. The API has been uploaded to Heroku.

Thoughts

I’ve had a blast setting up my todo API GET requests, you can GET all todos, as well as a single todo, using the route ‘/todos/:id’.

The app has been deployed to Heroku, and the MongoDB server has been set up through the Heroku addon ‘mLab MongoDB’.

Also, some test cases have been set up to ensure the correct data is being requested, and that a 404 will successfully show if using an invalid ObjectID or a todo wasn’t found in the database.

entry.title: Day 16
entry.content:
Today’s Progress

I managed to lose count of my hours this evening, but I’ve done at least 3 hours. I did some more MongoDB stuff and I’ve learned about connecting to the server, inserting data and removing data. I learned about the ‘deleteOne’, ‘deleteMany’, ‘findOneAndDelete’, ‘insertOne’, and finding data based on certain criteria.

Thoughts

I’ve had a lot of fun with MongoDB, and I think I’m understanding it. Obviously there’s a long way to go, but I’m happy with what I’ve learned thus far.

I did come away from the course and I attempted to connect and insert data from memory, but I needed to refer back for a few things.

A problem I have noticed, though, is that the course is using MongoDB version 2.2.5, but when I referred to the docs for help, I noticed that version 3 no longer returns a database object as it did in version 2, but rather a client object.

The following is what I had learned as per v2:

  MongoClient.connect('mongodb://localhost:27017/mytestingdb', (err, db) => {
    // Database returned
  });

And here is the client object as per v3:

  MongoClient.connect('mongodb://localhost:27017', (err, client) => {
    // Client returned
    var db = client.db('mytestingdb');
  });

Also, the close() method has been moved to the client:

  MongoClient.connect('mongodb://localhost', function (err, client) {
    if (err) throw err;

    var db = client.db('mytestingdb');

    db.collection('customers').findOne({}, function (findErr, result) {
      if (findErr) throw findErr;
      console.log(result.name);
      client.close();
    });
  });

This isn’t a major ball-ache, but once the course is over, I think I’ll have an adjustment period.

Furthermore, I decided to take a break from MongoDB and returned to playing with Axios to finish up the evening. I attempted to play with the Twitch API again, and have discovered that the data I needed was within response.data.data, the second .data is an array which is what stifled me the other day when I couldn’t access the data.

entry.title: Day 15
entry.content:
Today’s Progress

Today I finished learning about testing code using Mocha. I learned about spies (though, I’ll be honest I have no idea what they’re for), and I learned about Rewire (again, no understanding at all). I have also dipped my toes into learning MongoDB.

Thoughts

So, I have finished the testing course, and I am excited to start using it in real-world apps, I am a little confused when it comes to spies and Rewire. I’m sure time will help with this.

I also began to learn about MongoDB, which I must admit, I have been really excited about.

I have used SQL over the years, and I have always wanted to learn more about MongoDB, so with a bit of luck, I’ll be able to adjust pretty easily. I suppose the hardest part is getting used to collections, documents, and fields as I’m finding them a little confusing.

I discovered a tool called RoboMongo which provides a GUI for your database; it will help me visualise what is happening behind the scenes whilst I get used to using a NoSQL database.

Next up, is making a ‘Todo’ API using MongoDB. It’s currently 06:15 and I have been up with the baby all night so the API will have to wait until tomorrow!
